subject: Re: [junit] Re: Making good use of testing effort
msgSnippet: Here s a recent take.  Does it help? http://blog.schauderhaft.de/2010/01/31/new-feature-of-junit-theories/ David Saff On Fri, Jan 29, 2010 at 10:53 AM,
messageBody:
Here's a recent take. Does it help?

http://blog.schauderhaft.de/2010/01/31/new-feature-of-junit-theories/

David Saff

On Fri, Jan 29, 2010 at 10:53 AM, Loritsch, Berin C.
<berin.loritsch@...> wrote:
> It looks interesting, but I haven't found a clear example of how to use
> them.
>
>
>
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
> David Saff
> Sent: Friday, January 29, 2010 9:34 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Making good use of testing effort
>
>
>
>
>
> Berin,
>
> Have you looked at Theories in JUnit 4?
>
> David Saff
>
> On Thu, Jan 28, 2010 at 12:28 PM, Loritsch, Berin C.
> <berin.loritsch@... <mailto:berin.loritsch%40gd-ais.com> > wrote:
>> I'm not so worried about the mechanics of each test.  That's the easy
>> problem.  I just want to be able to define the test once, and have it
>> automatically run on each attribute-each run being counted as a
> separate
>> test.
>>
>>
>>
>> In short I'm not sure about how suites and such work with JUnit 4.  I
>> had a tenuous grasp on it with JUnit 3, but found out quickly that
> many
>> assumptions in the code made my old solution a hack.  One such symptom
>> is that I had to create a dummy "testSomething()" method just to get
>> JUnit to run the suite.
>>
>>
>>
>> Think in terms of a test "macro" that is applied automatically to a
> set
>> of classes.  Using the example provided in the original email, I want
> to
>> make JUnit find all the classes that extends the Listenable base
> class,
>> collect the attributes, and perform the test on those attributes.
>>
>>
>>
>> I'm just not that sure of how the right way to go about it is.  I'm a
>> little gun shy based on my prior experience, and I'm thinking that a
>> little guidance to address this is best.
>>
>>
>>
>> The same type of solution would work well for automatically testing
> the
>> implementations of certain interfaces to ensure they are behaving as
> the
>> interface is designed.
>>
>>
>>
>> From: junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>
> [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> ] On
> Behalf Of
>> Georg
>> Sent: Thursday, January 28, 2010 9:25 AM
>> To: junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>
>> Subject: [junit] Re: Making good use of testing effort
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> Hi!
>>
>> I hope I understand correctly that you want to ensure that the
> listeners
>> are getting the right calls.
>>
>> If yes, you should look into extensions like jmock, easymock,...
>>
>> Cheers,
>> Georg
>>
>> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>
> <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com> ,
>> "Loritsch, Berin C." <berin.loritsch@...> wrote:
>>>
>>> I've got a challenge that I'm not sure how to approach with JUnit 4.
>>> I've sort of hacked something similar in JUnit3, but there were some
>>> inelegant things about it.
>>>
>>> Basic problem is that I have a bunch of setters and getters on my
>> domain
>>> models that have predictable side effects. Essentially, the model has
>> a
>>> listener infrastructure and if the user changes the value of the
> class
>>> attribute the appropriate event is supposed to fire. The typical
>>> setter/getter looks like this:
>>>
>>> class MyBean extends Listenable {
>>> String value;
>>>
>>> public String getValue() {
>>> return value;
>>> }
>>>
>>> public void setValue(String newValue) {
>>> fireAttributeChangedEvent("value", value, newValue);
>>> value = newValue;
>>> }
>>> }
>>>
>>> I need to test that the setters fire the appropriate event, and that
>> the
>>> event attribute name is correct. I want a test harness to essentially
>>> collect all the setters and getters and change the value to ensure
>> that
>>> the event is sent as expected. Then I want to run that against all my
>>> domain models.
>>>
>>> My understanding is that I need to generate a suite, and add the test
>>> instances to that suite. I've upgraded to JUnit 4 because I think it
>> is
>>> designed better. I'm just at a loss as to how to start. With JUnit 4,
>>> individual tests are marked with an annotation.
>>>
>>>
